awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Emerging Opportunities at the Intersection of Quantum and Thermal Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is to support the Workshop on Emerging Opportunities at the Intersection of Quantum and Thermal Sciences to be held virtually on June 28-30, 2021. Advances in quantum science over the past century have laid the foundation for both modern information technologies and solid-state energy-conversion devices that have emerged and altered the course of human history. As these classical devices and technologies approach their theoretical limits, progress is now being made to store information in quantum systems to enable secured quantum communication, quantum sensing, and quantum computation of complex problems that cannot be handled by current classical computers. Among the various grand challenges that need to be overcome for the establishment and deployment of quantum information technologies, innovative thermal science and engineering solutions are required for cooling the quantum hardware to an extremely low temperature. Meanwhile, thermal measurements can provide unique probes of exotic quantum materials and may provide unanticipated new directions in quantum hardware designs. In response to these challenges and opportunities, nineteen leading researchers in relevant fields have been invited to present forward-looking perspectives and participate in panel discussions in the three-day virtual workshop. The workshop is open to the broad research community, including both students and established researchers from different fields.

The goal of this three-day virtual workshop is to identify emerging research opportunities at the intersection of quantum and thermal sciences, especially on thermal challenges and opportunities in quantum computation and hardware, thermal science and engineering of quantum sensors and materials, and coherent phonons and magnons for quantum information technologies. This goal will be pursued via invited talks from leading experts in quantum and thermal science communities in US, Europe, and Israel, as well as panel discussions that will stimulate scientific exchanges and initiate interdisciplinary collaborations between the different communities in quantum theories, thermal science, material science, and advanced manufacturing. These cross-disciplinary interactions will help identify research needs in thermal science and engineering for advancing quantum information science and technologies.  The workshop is also expected to promote the applications of quantum sensing and computation for measurements and computation of thermal problems. These reciprocal interactions between quantum and thermal sciences will stimulate future research opportunities in materials science and advanced manufacturing for realizing thermal devices and components in quantum systems and quantum hardware for thermal applications. Besides identifying collaboration opportunities for the research communities, the workshop will contribute to the education of students from diverse backgrounds for the future workforce of the quantum information technology industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this three-day virtual workshop is to identify emerging research opportunities at the intersection of quantum and thermal sciences, especially on thermal challenges and opportunities in quantum computation and hardware, thermal science and engineering of quantum sensors and materials, and coherent phonons and magnons for quantum information technologies. The workshop program consists of invited talks from twenty-one leading experts in quantum and thermal science communities in US, Europe, and Israel, as well as panel discussions to stimulate scientific exchanges and initiate interdisciplinary collaborations between the different communities in quantum theories, thermal science, material science, and advanced manufacturing.

The workshop has highlighted the following recent progresses and recommended future directions in three topical areas at the intersection of quantum and thermal sciences:

Topic 1: Thermal Challenges and Opportunities in Quantum Computation and Hardware

This workshop has identified two thrusts within Topic 1, including (i) research into quantum algorithms to compute transport properties in condensed matter with reduced cost, and (ii) schemes to control thermal transport and realize novel active thermal elements by manipulating the macroscopic quantum phase of a condensate. As an example, solid-state thermal switches that can achieve high on-off ratios at temperatures near and below 4K may allow magnetocaloric and electrocaloric refrigerators to become a practical alternative to helium-3 dilution refrigeration units that house various qubit platforms.    

Topic 2: Thermal Science and Engineering of Quantum Sensors and  Materials

The intersection of quantum sensors, such as Nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers in diamond and nanoscale quantum interference devices, and thermal measurement techniques promise to have great potential impact on research on quantum materials and in the dynamic study of biological reactions with impact on cancer research.  The workshop identifies the need of new engineering ideas to simplify the implementation of quantum thermometers, improve their interface with biological and materials targets, and identify targets in material science and biology where thermal control brings new insight and functionality.  New types of qubit-based thermal sensors with similar sensitivity are expected to emerge. On the other hand, the development of novel thermal metrology methods can enable the identification of quantum transport channels. Even in electronic systems, the thermal measurement often provide more direct evidence for the phenomena than the electrical ones.  As the power of these techniques is increasingly recognized, conceptually, heat currents may constitute the communication channel between the quantum devices and the outside world.

Topic 3:  Coherent Phonons and Magnons for Quantum Information Technologies

Microwave frequency phonons in bulk and surface acoustic wave transducers have demonstrated the capabilities for entangling superconducting qubits, mediating remote qubit-qubit coupling, measuring quantum two-level systems, storing quantum information, and transducing quantum information between microwave frequency circuits and infrared lights. Recent experiments suggest the potential of controlling and manipulating individual phonons at the same level as photons to eventually allow all the photon-based quantum optics processes to be demonstrated with phonons. Meanwhile, magnons can be coherently coupled to NV centers in diamond and impurity spins in semiconductors, as well as superconducting qubits, which in turn enables measurement of magnons down to the single quantum limit.

The 21 invited speakers include 7 women, who inspire the participation of women in the emerging research at the intersection between quantum and thermal sciences.  Among the 368 registered participants of the workshop, there were 36 assistant professors, 48 post-doctoral fellows, and 86 graduate students. This workshop provided opportunities for these early stage researchers to learn about frontier research topics at the intersection of quantum and thermal sciences.
